questions.title: Welcome To Sandbox
questions.body: Sandbox is where you can test out the zite without the question appearing in any results on the "All" section of the zite.

questions.title: Test Markdown
questions.body:
*Testing Italics*
**Testing bold**
~~Strikethrough~~
# Heading
## Heading 2
### Heading 3
---
^ Line
* Test
* test
* test
  - Test

comments.body: Yeah, I know. I just wanted to test out the answer to make sure it works.

Thanks! There's still a bit to do, and I'm unsure about a few things regarding the UI (mostly the chip/tag thing at the top of the question and answer boxes). I'm thinking about switching ZeroMedium over to using this - which is using the MaterializeCss framework.
@Version Click the three lines that denote a menu bar. Then click login. After you have logged in, there will be a tab called `ask`. Click that.
@Version: Did you enter tags? Tags are required right now (I may change this in the future). Also, you need to press enter after every tag you want to add.

I do have plans for multi-language. However, I'm not sure if it would be better to just use seperate/new topics for them so that the names of the topics would be in the desired language vs. having a selection to mark a certain post as a certain language (which will require that all topics have some sort of setting to determine the name of it for other languages; and I'd have to find a way to hide/show certain posts based on secondary and primary languages as I do with ZeroMedium).

*testing new edit functionality*

answers.body: Currently, the form does tell you that you must hit enter below the input line. However, you are correct that it does not tell you that it is required to have tags - I will add this in the future.
This has not been implemented yet. It is on the todo list for the next version of ZeroExchange.

This has not been implemented *yet*.

**Edit:** I have implemented this for comments and answers. Editing Questions coming *soon*!

Okay, so how I solve this is by referencing the auth_address of the user who posted the comment along with the id of the comment. Therefore, comments can use same id's as long as it's from different people.

But, to make sure the id's are unique for that one user, you need to implement a keyvalue that stores that next id to be used and then increment that when a new comment is posted. Then, you can use that value as the id for the next comment. This is what I did at first. **However**, there's an easier way, which is to just store that date the comment was posted as the id - this solution is *much* simpler than the other one.

There is technically the problem where if the user's time on their computer is wrong, then there could technically be overlap, but I think the chance of that happening is pretty low, imo.
